items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
This flood alert has been issued due to high spring tides combined with strong winds. 

The first forecast high water is 22:00 on 04/08/23 with a level of 6.46 mAOD and a Force 4 North Westerly wind. 
The second forecast high water is 10:15 on 05/08/23 with a level of 6.31 mAOD and a Force 7 South Westerly wind. 

All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Due to increasing wind strength, there is a risk of property flooding so Flood Warnings may be issued for tomorrow mornings tide.

Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides on Saturday 05/08/2023. We will update this message as necessary.

This message will be updated by 15:00 on Saturday, 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.86mAOD at 05:15 on 04/08/23 and 4.68mAOD at 17:30 on 04/08/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 40 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remainlow for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/08/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Gaunless
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We may see further rainfall over the next few days and this Flood Alert will be re-issued if needed.
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from trash screens.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Friday’s early morning tide at 01:45 on 04/08/2023 is forecast to be a little lower than recent high waters, but still higher than normal due to unsettled weather. A very small amount of water could still find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Flood risk should reduce over the week ahead. However, low pressure on Saturday could see the return of some larger waves and minor flood risk again. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be moved by waves. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Coastal conditions have now passed. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 1:30pm and 3:30pm this afternoon, Friday 4th August. High tide levels are forecast to just reach the Flood Alert threshold. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.51mAODN at 2:30pm on Friday 4th August, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind force 1, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 3:00am on Saturday 5th August may also reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 4th August.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: Water levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast for the next couple of days is for more unsettled weather which could result in further high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 1:30pm and 3:30pm this afternoon, Friday 4th August. High tide levels are forecast to just reach the Flood Alert threshold. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.51mAODN at 2:30pm on Friday 4th August, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind force 1, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 3:00am on Saturday 5th August may also reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 4th August.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 1:30pm and 3:30pm this afternoon, Friday 4th August. High tide levels are forecast to just reach the Flood Alert threshold. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.71mAODN at 2:30pm on Friday 4th August, which is 0.25m above tide tables, wind force 1, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 3:15am on Saturday 5th August may also reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 4th August.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible today (04/08/2023). Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Upper Derwent around Low Marishes Levels are rising steadily and further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday (05/08/2024) or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
As a result of spring tides, water levels will be at their highest this evening at 10:30 PM on 04/08/2023.

Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.

The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.50 mAODN, which is 0.03 m above tide tables, with westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.)

We are closing flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton and we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

We will remove this message by 09:00 AM on 05/08/2023.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 9pm and 10pm this evening, 04/08/23. Flooding of roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.5m Friday evening and 7.3 to 7.4m Saturday morning.  Newport 7.1m to 7.2m Friday evening and 6.8 to 7.1 m Saturday morning, 05/08/23
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on 05/08/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Crane

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
The high tide at Richmond has now passed, and fluvial levels on the River Crane have now fallen below levels of concern.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast in the coming days which may lead to high fluvial levels on the River Crane.

We will continue to monitor the river level and observe weather and tide forecasts and will issue any new flood messages when needed.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
The high tide is expected to be higher than usual at the Mersey Estuary at Warrington as a result of high spring tides.  Consequently, flooding of low lying land is possible tomorrow morning, 04/08/23, peaking at 2 am at the following places:

Fiddlers Ferry will peak at 6.3 meters,

Eastford Road will peak at 6.45 meters,

Arpley Bridge will peak at 6.5 meters.

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.   

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation and will issue flood warnings if necessary.

Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

This message will be updated when the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
The mid-day high tide today 04/08/2023, is not expected to exceed warning levels. However we are in a period of spring tides and tonight's high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 04/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible at high spring tides Friday evening 04/08/23 with high water at Ilfracombe 21:07. On Saturday morning 05/08/23, Storm Antoni is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast.  High water at Ilfracombe at 09:30. Times of high water will vary along the coast

Force 7 north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 2.8m are forecast, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.28m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. This message will be updated by noon on 05/08/23 or as the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Friday at 21:07 is 5.04 mAOD, this is 0.04 metres above astronomical tide level. The forecast high tide level on Saturday at 09:30 is 4.85 mAOD, this is 0.28 metres above astronomical tide level.
